articles.content:
Samuel Green Freed Himself and Others From Slavery. Then He Was Imprisoned Over Owning a Book
After buying his own liberty, the Marylander covertly assisted conductors on the Underground Railroad, including Harriet Tubman. But his possession of ‚ÄúUncle Tom‚Äôs Cabin‚Äù turned him into an abolitionist hero
The knock on Samuel Green‚Äôs door must have felt inevitable. It was April 1857, and in the past decade hundreds of Black Marylanders had slipped off the farms and plantations where they were enslaved. Now local white leaders were beginning to suspect that Green knew more about the runaways than he let on. Green was a free Black man who lived in a cottage in Dorchester County, on the Eastern Shore of the Chesapeake Bay, where he farmed a modest plot and preached the word of God. Opening his door that April evening, Green came face to face with the law. ‚ÄúYou are suspected of holding correspondence with the North,‚Äù a county sheriff told him, ‚Äúand I shall search your house.‚Äù
The sheriff and his posse soon found what they were looking for: a letter from Green‚Äôs son, Sam Jr.; a map of Canada; railroad schedules for northbound trains; and a copy of Uncle Tom‚Äôs Cabin, Harriet Beecher Stowe‚Äôs blockbuster antislavery novel, published five years earlier. None of the items proved that Green had helped usher anyone to freedom‚Äîbut the book turned out to be sufficiently incriminating. Green was placed under arrest. Then he was charged, under an obscure Maryland law, with possessing an ‚Äúabolition pamphlet‚Äù that could ‚Äúcreate discontent amongst the people of color of this state.‚Äù As he sat in a jail cell, awaiting his trial, state prosecutors began to craft an ominous argument: A person caught reading the wrong kind of book deserved to be locked away.
It was no accident that Green‚Äôs unprecedented case unfolded in Maryland, where slavery‚Äôs position at the center of American life was at its most tenuous. Maryland had the largest free Black population of any state in the nation. It was also the state from which the greatest number of people fled slavery, Frederick Douglass and Harriet Tubman, who may have been a distant relative of Green‚Äôs, among them. Trapped between the slavery-powered economy of the South and the industrial North, Black people in Maryland had long negotiated freedom however they could. During the Revolutionary War, enslaved Marylanders escaped to British ships anchored in the Chesapeake Bay after Virginia‚Äôs colonial governor, Lord Dunmore, offered emancipation to enslaved people who defected to the British Army.
Did You Know? Maryland and the Civil War
-
In 1861, Maryland‚Äôs pro-slavery governor, Thomas Hicks, was also a committed Unionist, while the state legislature, like the state‚Äôs population, was deeply divided over whether to secede
-
On April 26, the legislature voted against secession, but the next day President Lincoln, fearful of a secessionist uprising, suspended the writ of habeas corpus in Maryland, clearing a path to arrest treasonous actors; in May, Baltimore was placed under martial law, and the federal government largely controlled the state during the course of the war.
After the war, some of Dorchester County‚Äôs white leaders proposed abolishing slavery in the state, following the lead of neighboring Pennsylvania. The effort failed, but individual enslavers freed more than 1,600 enslaved people in the county before 1820. Most of the manumissions stemmed from the strong strain of Methodism in Maryland and the abolitionist teachings of John Wesley, the founder of the Methodist Church. With some restrictions, the earliest of these formerly enslaved people entered a Maryland society where they could vote, own property and testify in court.
Green was born in bondage around 1802 in East New Market, a village in northeast Dorchester County. He worked as a farm laborer and may have been ‚Äúhired out‚Äù to work on other farms, an arrangement that sometimes gave enslaved people the chance to keep a portion of the fee they earned. Before Green‚Äôs enslaver Henry Nichols died in 1832, Nichols decreed in his will that Green be freed five years after his death. Green refused to wait; by working long hours, he raised enough money to purchase his liberty from Nichols‚Äô beneficiaries within a year. In 1842, he purchased the freedom of his wife, Kitty, for $100, though their two children, Sam Jr. and Sarah, remained enslaved.
Green and Kitty joined Maryland‚Äôs growing number of free Black people, who totaled more than 40 percent of the Black population by 1840. Many worked as laborers, others as blacksmiths, butchers, carpenters and in other skilled trades. Nearly 2,500 free Black Marylanders were property owners. Green himself, mild-mannered, literate and devoutly religious, spent much of his time spreading the Gospel. He was a licensed ‚Äúexhorter,‚Äù a role in the Methodist Church that allowed him to preach to Black people, both free and enslaved. He also served as a founding trustee for a church in East New Market, the Colored People‚Äôs Methodist Episcopal Church. Black and white Marylanders acknowledged his contributions to the community, calling him ‚Äúintelligent‚Äù and ‚Äúexceedingly useful‚Äù in contemporaneous accounts. ‚ÄúHe was able to build skills and build relationships beyond Henry Nichols‚Äô plantation,‚Äù says Kate Clifford Larson, the author of the Harriet Tubman biography Bound for the Promised Land and an expert on the Underground Railroad. ‚ÄúHe had networks of people, and that helped him navigate the world.‚Äù
But even as Green eked out a life for himself and his wife, he witnessed a growing racial backlash as Maryland steadily turned against its earlier notions of Black liberty. Voting rights had been completely stripped from Black men in 1810, following the loss of the right to testify in court. The pace of manumissions had slowed as the Methodist Church dropped calls for abolition in order to appease wealthy white enslavers, who broke off from the larger church to form a Southern faction that endorsed slavery. Many enslavers began selling Black Marylanders to the plantations of the Deep South as demand for field labor grew with the rise of the cotton crop. Others became fervent supporters of the so-called colonization movement, a decades-long effort to ship Black Americans to Africa.
Discrimination in Maryland increased in the 1830s after Nat Turner‚Äôs failed rebellion in Virginia. Maryland lawmakers launched sweeping efforts to limit the mobility of both the free and the enslaved. Free Black people from other states were banned from entering Maryland, and religious gatherings were outlawed unless they were overseen by white clergymen. Another law decreed that Black sailors could no longer operate large boats. In 1851, a new Maryland state constitution enshrined protections to ‚Äúlife, liberty and property‚Äù for white men and ominously granted the legislature the power of ‚Äúregulation and disposition of the free colored population...as they may deem necessary.‚Äù ‚ÄúHardly a session of the legislature passes, that some law is not enacted, restricting [free Black people] in their rights and privileges,‚Äù a legislative committee noted in a report from the era.
Maryland‚Äôs impositions mirrored the nation‚Äôs. The Fugitive Slave Act, passed in 1850, required that runaways in free states be returned to their enslavers, often by federally sanctioned slave catchers. Horror stories spread of runaways or even free Black people kidnapped as far north as Philadelphia or Boston and shipped South. ‚ÄúSlaveholders...mean to cling to their slaves as long as they can, and to the bitter end,‚Äù remarked Frederick Douglass (who, like Green, had been born and enslaved on Maryland‚Äôs Eastern Shore). ‚ÄúThey show no sign of a wish to quit their iron grasp upon the sable throats of their victims.‚Äù
Green observed these developments with alarm. Though he had climbed out of slavery, he saw that even he and his free neighbors in Dorchester County were not truly free. He would later recall an incident where a white Marylander told him that he‚Äôd ‚Äúrather go to hell and be damned than go to heaven with a n----r.‚Äù
Green began doing what he could to upend ‚Äúthe evil of slavery,‚Äù as he later put it, attending conferences like the Convention of Free Colored People in Baltimore, where Black leaders debated the best course of action in a darkening social climate. But with two fully grown children who were still enslaved, he came to feel that it wasn‚Äôt enough to talk.
By 1854, Green‚Äôs son, Samuel Green Jr. could no longer stand a life in bondage. He and his sister, Sarah, by then in their mid-20s, had been sold several years earlier to James Muse, a Dorchester County physician Sam Jr. called ‚Äúthe worst man in Maryland‚Äù on account of his vicious whippings and abuse. One day late that summer, Sam Jr. visited his father. ‚ÄúI must fly for freedom,‚Äù he told him.
Sam Jr. had already been mulling an escape for months, since he had met a local runaway who had managed to flee and then, shockingly, returned to help free others. Newspaper ads demanding the runaway‚Äôs capture called her ‚ÄúMinty,‚Äù but the Greens and the rest of America would eventually know her as Harriet Tubman. Tubman hailed from the Dorchester County community of Bucktown, about nine miles southwest of Sam Green‚Äôs home. Her escape in September 1849 was not unusual‚Äîin the 1850 census, Maryland recorded 279 runaways, more than anywhere else in the Union. Over the next decade, nearly 100 more would flee from Dorchester County alone. These runaways faced brutal repercussions if captured. Some received 20 lashes from their captors and more beatings when they were returned to their enslavers. Others were branded with an ‚ÄúR‚Äù (for runaway) on their cheek. Packs of Maryland bloodhounds were often contracted to catch escapees throughout the state.
Most of those who made it out never returned to the Eastern Shore. Tubman came back again and again. On at least 13 return trips to Maryland, she guided some 70 people to freedom and aided dozens more with advice about optimal escape routes, often conveyed in coded messages via songs. She became the most famous ‚Äúconductor‚Äù on the Underground Railroad. ‚ÄúI never ran my train off the track, and I never lost a passenger,‚Äù she said later.
Tubman often worked to free members of her extended family throughout Dorchester County. She tended to bring them through a rural area called Poplar Neck along the Choptank River in neighboring Caroline County, where her parents, also agents of the Underground Railroad, lived. From there, she would guide her runaway companions by foot or wagon over the Delaware border to Dover, then to Wilmington and eventually into Philadelphia and beyond. Sometimes she traveled north by boat to Baltimore and through the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal. The journeys typically ended in the city of St. Catharines in Ontario, where hundreds of liberated people eventually settled.
In the spring of 1854, while she was back in Dorchester to rescue her brothers, Tubman gave Sam Jr. instructions on the best route to Philadelphia. Sam Jr. then worked up the courage to tell his father. Soon afterward, he fled. From Canada, he wrote home to his father urging more enslaved people to follow. ‚ÄúTell P. Jackson to come on, Bailey to come on,‚Äù Sam Jr. wrote. ‚ÄúCome more.‚Äù
It‚Äôs not clear when the elder Green became involved with the Underground Railroad. He may have already been working as an agent on the secretive network before his son fled, or his son‚Äôs plight under a violent enslaver may have motivated him to do more to combat slavery. Whatever the case, he became a key partner in Tubman‚Äôs many rescues. He shared a surname with Tubman‚Äôs mother and may have been a distant relative, according to Larson, the Tubman scholar. Green‚Äôs home, just west of East New Market, became a refuge where runaways could hide from police and vigilantes hunting for them. And thanks to his relationship to the Methodist Church, he had connections to friendly Black and white residents along the Eastern Shore. Green was important enough to her missions that Tubman mentioned him by name when, late in her life, she recalled her most common Underground Railroad routes in an interview with the historian Wilbur Siebert. ‚ÄúPeople like Tubman, heroes that we celebrate, they never do anything all on their own,‚Äù Larson says. ‚ÄúShe could not have done what she did without the help of other people.‚Äù
The escape of Sam Jr.‚Äôs friend Joe Bailey was among the most dramatic Tubman helped orchestrate, and Green played a key role. Bailey, an enslaved lumber foreman tasked with chopping timber along the Choptank River, was regularly whipped by his enslaver, a business magnate named William Hughlett. Bailey and his brother Bill enlisted Tubman‚Äôs help to run away. The route north from Dorchester County usually took three or four days, but it took Tubman and the Bailey brothers more than two weeks due to long periods of hiding from slave catchers. (Joe Bailey had an exorbitant $1,500 bounty on his head.) Green opened his home to Tubman and the Baileys as their pursuers scoured the region. Once in Wilmington, the group enlisted the help of some local Black bricklayers, who hid them in a secret compartment of their wagon while they rode past patrolling police.
The group eventually made it to safety in Canada. But the growing number of escapees incensed the Eastern Shore‚Äôs enslaver class. With suspicion turning on the region‚Äôs free Black population, Black schools without white supervision were banned, and police searches of Black people‚Äôs homes became common. Whispers about Green‚Äôs involvement in the Underground Railroad grew louder after every escape. ‚ÄúThere is no doubt of the fact that Green was instrumental, and had been for a long time, in the escape of slaves from this county,‚Äù the Easton Gazette, a pro-slavery paper in nearby Talbot County, editorialized after his arrest.
After Sam Jr. escaped, his sister, Sarah, was sold to an enslaver on the Missouri frontier as an apparent punishment, separating her from her husband and two small children. (No records indicate that the Greens ever spoke to Sarah again.) Desperate for the remaining family members to reunite, Sam Jr. wrote a letter imploring his father to ‚Äúlet us all live together here‚Äù in Canada. In the winter of 1856-57, Green secretly traveled to Ontario to see his son and assess whether the family could earn a living in the far north. When he returned, he told Kitty to prepare to leave Dorchester County for good.
But Green had not been as discreet as he imagined. The Easton Gazette later reported that local enslavers found out about his trip to Canada. When, shortly after he returned, a group of local enslaved people known as the ‚ÄúDover Eight‚Äù made a dramatic escape, gaining national attention and embarrassing the community‚Äôs enslavers, they took action. Having identified Green as a suspect, they now focused on conjuring the necessary evidence‚Äîand latched on to Uncle Tom‚Äôs Cabin as the proof they needed.
The red-brick Dorchester County courthouse was the opulent centerpiece of the county seat of Cambridge, but for Black Marylanders the building was another symbol of terror. Frequent human auctions were conducted outside, with merchants of flesh placing bids on enslaved men, women and children from a hotel veranda across the street.
Inside the courthouse, in the spring of 1857, prosecutors began to build their case against Green. They seized on an 1841 act, applied only once before, that outlawed the possession of ‚Äúinflammatory‚Äù material that could ‚Äúcreate discontent‚Äù or foment ‚Äúinsurrection‚Äù among the Black population. The law only impacted free Black people, another sign of how much Maryland lawmakers feared their growing presence in the state; white people were free to read and write abolitionist material (though they could be punished for failing to inform police if they knew free Black Marylanders who were violating the law).
At first, state attorneys focused on the map and the railroad schedules that police had found in Green‚Äôs home. But Green‚Äôs defense argued that documents with such a broad use could not be narrowly defined as abolitionist or otherwise used to sow discontent among Dorchester County‚Äôs enslaved population. The judge agreed, and Green was found not guilty on this indictment.
The prosecutors next turned to his copy of Uncle Tom‚Äôs Cabin. In the five years since its publication, the novel had gripped Northern readers with its unflinching account of slavery‚Äôs brutalities and its humanizing portrayals of its enslaved characters. Two million copies had been sold by the time of Green‚Äôs trial. In the South, however, enslavers, pro-slavery newspapers and other civic leaders railed against the text, arguing that it was radicalizing Black people and indoctrinating white children. In Athens, Georgia, copies of the book were burned. In Mobile, Alabama, vigilantes reportedly forced a bookseller to flee town after he featured the novel in his shop. But only Maryland was attempting to throw someone in jail for owning it.
Green had been given his copy by a blacksmith only a few months earlier, according to a newspaper account, while he was headed to a local mill. Before that chance encounter, he wasn‚Äôt even aware of the book, and at the time of the arrest he hadn‚Äôt yet finished reading it. But prosecutors insisted that the trial was about more than objects seized from Green‚Äôs home. The novel, they argued, threatened the very foundation of their society: If the legitimacy of slavery began to crumble, the Union would go with it. ‚ÄúSlavery must be protected or it must be abolished,‚Äù the assistant counsel argued for the state.
The gambit worked. The same judge who had earlier ruled in Green‚Äôs favor now ruled that Uncle Tom‚Äôs Cabin‚Äîa work of fiction‚Äîmet the criteria of an ‚Äúabolitionist pamphlet‚Äù described in the 1841 law. Green, born into enslavement, then freed at 30, was now sentenced to ten years in prison. He was immediately transferred to Baltimore‚Äôs Maryland State Penitentiary.
The news of the verdict made waves across the country. In South Carolina, a Charleston Courier columnist argued that the facts were so unreasonable that Northern abolitionists must have made them up to demonize the planter class‚Äî‚Äútoo impossible and absurd to be anything but false,‚Äù he wrote. Other Southerners welcomed Green‚Äôs imprisonment, with the Easton Gazette calling it a ‚Äúrighteous verdict.‚Äù
Northern writers used Green‚Äôs arrest to illustrate how poisonous slavery had become, corrupting basic rights to free expression. ‚ÄúAll the annals of the Spanish or Roman Inquisitions could not show a more degrading fact,‚Äù fumed an editorial in the New Bedford Mercury in Massachusetts. The Liberator, the abolitionist paper founded by William Lloyd Garrison, castigated the Maryland lawmakers who had passed ‚Äúa statute capable of being abused for so cruel and tyrannical a purpose.‚Äù In Kansas, the Lawrence Republican wrote that Green‚Äôs conviction was ‚Äúa burning disgrace upon the civilization, upon the age, and especially upon the character and name of our nation.‚Äù
But not even widespread outrage would get Green out of prison. Green hoped for a pardon from a pair of successive Maryland governors, Thomas Watkins Ligon and Thomas Holliday Hicks, the second of whom was a Dorchester County native whom Green later claimed to know personally. Two dozen local farmers, merchants and teachers in the East New Market area quickly signed a petition seeking clemency for Green. A group of Maryland ministers did the same, while 114 Methodist clergymen from as far away as New York rallied to Green‚Äôs cause with their own petition. But Ligon and Hicks, under pressure from local enslavers, both refused to help Green.
If Green‚Äôs imprisonment was meant to deter runaways and the networks that aided them, it didn‚Äôt work. In October 1857, six months after Green‚Äôs arrest, a group of 28 runaways escaped Dorchester County at one time. Escapes continued into 1858. Tubman kept returning until 1860, seeking to rescue her sister Rachel and other relatives. By then, the country was careening toward war.
At the start of 1861, after seven Southern states voted to secede from the Union, Maryland was torn over what to do. Many people in Maryland were Confederate sympathizers, but the state was deeply divided over entering the war. Because of Maryland‚Äôs strategic position bordering the capital, President Abraham Lincoln took steps to ensure federal control. After state legislators voted against secession in April, Baltimore was placed under martial law anyway, and the federal government largely controlled state governance throughout the Civil War.
Green remained imprisoned as war broke out, but in 1862, his fortunes finally reversed. A Union loyalist named Augustus Bradford was elected governor of Maryland. One of his confidants was Francis Thompson King, a well-connected Baltimore Quaker who had taken an interest in Green‚Äôs plight. King visited Green in prison and advised Bradford on Green‚Äôs case multiple times. The many petitions demanding Green‚Äôs release from Methodist leaders and East New Market locals were also still on the books. At the collective urging of Methodist and Quaker ministers, Bradford pardoned Green as one of his first official actions as governor.
On April 21, 1862, Green finally walked free for the second and last time.
Three months later, Green stood before an expectant crowd outside Boston. ‚ÄúI have been truly gratified in hearing what has been said in regard to the evil of slavery,‚Äù he declared, ‚Äúand the terrible consequences thereof, which now convulse the nation.‚Äù America was changing fast. In a few months, Lincoln‚Äôs Emancipation Proclamation would nominally free the nation‚Äôs slaves‚Äîbut not in border states that remained in the Union, such as Maryland. Green would have understood better than most how what was legal and what was just could often be at odds. Even in the case of his own pardon, one of the stipulations was that he leave the state of Maryland within 60 days.
He was 60 years old now but younger in spirit; the Liberator described him as ‚Äúgood-looking, intelligent and amiable.‚Äù Though he still hoped to join his son in Canada, he had little money, so he traveled the Northeast on a makeshift lecture tour, handing out a collection plate after each speech to help fund a new life. In Philadelphia, he sat down with William Still, a devoted chronicler of the enslaved people who traveled the Underground Railroad. In New York, he gave a speech that was mentioned by the New York Times.
That summer he also got to meet a pivotal figure in his life: Harriet Beecher Stowe. He visited the novelist in her home and told her of his travails since stumbling upon her book. ‚ÄúAll this was his portion of the cross,‚Äù Stowe wrote in the
abolitionist newspaper the Independent in 1862, ‚Äúand he took it meekly, without comment.‚Äù Green asked her for a new copy of Uncle Tom‚Äôs Cabin, so he could finally finish it. She was happy to oblige.
Green and Kitty eventually made it to Canada, where they likely waited out the Civil War. But Canada was not home. By the end of the decade, the couple was back in Dorchester County.
Life was hardly idyllic; because Maryland had not been a Confederate state, it wasn‚Äôt placed under the Reconstruction-era mandates that allowed Black politics to flourish, albeit briefly, in the South after the Civil War. But the chains had been broken. The prosecutor who put Green in jail had once declared that slavery must be protected or abolished. Finally, the pendulum of justice swung in Green‚Äôs favor. Three years before he died in 1877, a Baltimore newspaper noted the irony: ‚ÄúHe has grown to be a respected citizen in the very county where once he was persecuted.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Lost City of the Silk Road‚Äù (December 2025) merits a couple of reads because it covers so much history and sociology. I am always delighted when my old assumptions‚Äîand those of the teachers who introduced me to them‚Äîare proved wrong. It is always because history, biology and sociology are so much more nuanced and varied than we ever thought. Here‚Äôs to the persistent archaeologists who are spending so much time and effort expanding our ideas about an ancient culture that was truly amazing.‚ÄîSandra Woodall | San Antonio
Saving Them All?
A big thank you to Douglas Starr for his cover story (‚ÄúGimme Shelter,‚Äù December 2025) on Best Friends Animal Society. Starr was admirable in his effort to wrap his arms around the extensive work and mission of Best Friends. I‚Äôd like to offer some context to Paulette Dean‚Äôs description of what she deemed a ‚Äúpressure campaign‚Äù organized by Best Friends in Danville, Virginia, when she declined our offers of support. In 2023, state records show roughly 80 percent of the
animals entering the Danville shelter did not make it out alive. Best Friends could have shrugged and walked away while healthy pets continued to die. Rather, we helped organize the citizens of Danville who didn‚Äôt want pets being unnecessarily killed in their community. Turning a blind eye would have made us complicit in that shelter‚Äôs abuse of the animals in their care. It‚Äôs unfortunate that some people personalized attacks toward Ms. Dean. Best Friends does not condone this behavior; however, we do condone positive lifesaving change, which we‚Äôve spearheaded in every type of community in America.‚ÄîJulie Castle | CEO, Best Friends Animal Society
Best Friends Animal Society‚Äôs push for an arbitrary ‚Äúno-kill‚Äù benchmark pressures shelters to turn away animals rather than admit and possibly euthanize them. This causes more suffering and deaths. Rejected animals reproduce‚Äîcreating even more with nowhere to go‚Äîand many are abandoned to die of starvation, injuries, exposure and disease. Animals admitted to ‚Äúno-kill‚Äù facilities are often warehoused in crowded conditions and die in cages. Shelters must prioritize animals‚Äô best interests and public safety by keeping doors open to all. Spay/neuter laws and affordable sterilization are the humane ways to address overpopulation.‚ÄîTeresa Chagrin | Animal care and control issues manager, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
As a rescue pup parent and animal shelter volunteer, I connect with Best Friends‚Äô mission to avoid non-medically needed animal euthanasia and use nonaggressive training approaches. I also appreciated hearing from some of the organization‚Äôs detractors, as no person or organization is perfect. Thank you for putting a spotlight on the work of this great organization.‚ÄîCorrine Melissari | Alexandria, Virginia

Biologists Reveal How Same-Sex Sexual Behavior May Have Given Some Primates an Evolutionary Advantage
Nonhuman primates like bonobos and chimpanzees might engage in same-sex sexual activities to strengthen bonds, particularly in harsh environments or within strict social structures, a new study suggests
Humans aren‚Äôt the only creatures engaging in same-sex sexual activities. To date, scientists have documented around 1,500 species, including whales, birds and fish, engaging in such behavior.
Now, an extensive review of hundreds of nonhuman primate species suggests that same-sex behavior isn‚Äôt just common among these animals‚Äîit may also help them reinforce social bonds and survive longer. The study, published January 12 in the journal Nature Ecology and Evolution, hints that sexual activities between members of the same sex might provide an evolutionary advantage, particularly in harsh environments or within strict social structures.
‚ÄúWhat we found shows that same-sex [behavior] is not like something bizarre, aberrant or rare. It‚Äôs everywhere, it‚Äôs very useful, it‚Äôs very important,‚Äù says study co-author Vincent Savolainen, an evolutionary biologist at Imperial College London, to Evan Bush at NBC News.
Past research has shown that primates like macaques, bonobos and chimpanzees engage in same-sex behavior. But scientists hadn‚Äôt previously conducted a comprehensive review of these activities across nonhuman primate species, and they‚Äôre not sure what purpose they might serve, the study authors write.
So, Savolainen and his colleagues found 96 published studies with observations of same-sex individuals mounting, touching genitals or engaging in other sexual acts. Those works involved 491 species, and 59 of them were seen engaging in same-sex behavior. The team considered the activities common in 23 of the analyzed species.
Moreover, same-sex activities happened more often in drier environments with less food and a higher risk of predation, the team found. And nonhuman primate species that live longer, have more pronounced differences between males and females or have stricter social hierarchies also seemed more likely to engage in the behavior.
The findings suggest that same-sex sexual behavior might be adaptive, particularly among animals with complex social systems. Being socially flexible might help primates manage conflict, ease tension and strengthen their social bonds.
‚ÄúIf you want to understand the behavior of wild, complex animals, you must take into account same-sex [behavior],‚Äù Savolainen tells Jackie Flynn Mogensen at Scientific American. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs, I believe, as important as reproductive sex, looking after kids, fighting, eating and so on.‚Äù
Did you know? Complex social systems may have changed the brain
Some scientists suspect that primates‚Äîincluding humans‚Äîmay have evolved big brains in response to the social challenges of group living.
Isabelle Winder, an evolutionary anthropologist at Bangor University in Wales who was not involved in the research, tells Nature's Ewen Callaway that the paper examines a seemingly rare behavior in animals in a groundbreaking way. The methodology could be applied to research on mourning, tool use and symbolic language, she says.
The study authors note that their findings might not apply to humans. Rather than food scarcity or rigid social hierarchies, the ‚Äúpressures of modern social living‚Äù may have driven same-sex behaviors in this species, they write.
But Josh Davis, a science writer at the Natural History Museum in London and author of A Little Gay Natural History, cautions against such speculation. He tells the Guardian‚Äôs Nicola Davis that a variety of queer behaviors are found in nature, and the reasons behind them likely differ.
‚ÄúPeople are complex and a result of a whole range of different factors separate from other animals, making these comparisons and extrapolations incredibly contentious,‚Äù Davis says.

Of course to call this eatery and brewery a ‚Äúrestaurant‚Äù vastly understates its place as a historical icon along Route 66 in Amarillo, Te
